row.cell:
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
Le réseau de cable télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie
constitue le moyen de communication le plus
direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique
du Nord et du Sud, L,Afrique orientale, méridionale
et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.
Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes
doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern.
Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu'à
Londres au belletin journalier publié dans ce journal.

Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Bureau principal à Londres.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: PORT ARTHUR.
div.p: The fall of Port Arthur brings to a close the first greet phase of the war in the Par East, a phase that has been prolonged beyond all calculations by Stoessel's obstinate and heroic resistance. The temptation to moralise is almost irresistible. The ignomi- nious end of the great squadron of the Pacific, the gradual crumbling of tho almost im- pregnable fortifications are in themselves both a sermon on the vanity of human wishes, and an illustration of what foresight and organisation can achieve when united to discipline, to oourage, and to patriotism. But the practical and strategical lemons to be learnednom this long siege ere of even greater interest to us as a maritime Power, and they deserve to be studied the more caretully be- cause of th' erroneous deductions to which the catastrophe of Port Arthur may give rise. Because the valour of the Kussian soldiers sad sailors has been in vain, and because the Russian Empire has suffered a humiliation to which the capture of Sebastopol was as nothing, it has been suggested by some authorities, end especially by the military correspondent of the Times, that fortifications are themselves a delusion and a snare, that the harbour of Port Arthur has been like a fatal magnet to the ships of the squadron, and that Kuropstkin should have begun his campaign by withdraw- ing every man and every movable gun from the Liao-tang Peninsula. In other words, Port Arthur is claimed to have been what Metz actually was, and what Ladysmith nearly became—a fatal entanglement, engulfing its own garrison, and finally compromising the forces outside of it by robbing them of the power of initiative. Had Stdessel got the gar- rison away while the railway was unout, had Stark or Makaroff sailed off with the remnants of their fleet, the abandonment of Port Arthur itself; the enormous lost ot material, and the blow to Russian prestige, would have been more than compensated for by the freedom which it would have given to Kuropatkin from his first arrival on the scene.

Such an inference and such a teaching are, in our judgment, not only wrong, but highly dangerous, as tending to discredit the value of naval bases end garrisons to a maritime Power alike in peace and in war. They ignore the faot that the misfortunes of the Russian Fleet have been due solely and entirely to its own in- efficiency and to the incapacity of those who directed its movements. The ruin dates from the first night of the war, when the Japanese torpedo-boats were allowed to work their will, end it was completed by the reluotanoe and inability of the blockaded squadron to give battle to the adversary in open water. If the Russian Fleet had been bandied as the fleet of a first-class Power ought to be, and as every country has a right to expect from its naval officers, Port Arthur would have been an absolutely invaluable asset to Russia during the war, and the march of the Japanese armies on Manchuria would have been definitely delayed. A glance at the map shows that Port Arthur is an ideal "point d'appui" for any nation at war with Japan; and its importance can best be realised by the pro- digious sacrifices which the latter Power has undergone during the process of reducing it. Nor does it seem to be realised how much the prolongation of the siege has actually affected the course of the campaign ; to say nothing of the fearful loss of men, which will be felt more and more as the war drags, it deprived the Japanese of the superiority in numbers which would have turned the battle of Liao-yang into another Leipaic. And it has so absolutely absorbed the energies of Admiral Togo that he has been unable-to spare a single ship from his fleet of observation, even when the cruisers of Skrydloff were ravaging in the home waters of Japan. Had the Baltic Fleet been able to sail in the early summer, as Captain Mahan anticipated, the Japanese com- mander would have found himself in the presence of a dilemma which might well have proved fatal.

Indeed, the supreme importance of a well- fortified and well-garrisoned naval base has never been so dearly indicated, unless we go beck to the siege of Gibraltar in 1779-83. And the conclusion to ourselves ought to be irresistible. Our own naval bases, to say nothing of minor ooaling stations, are scattered over every see, and their retention at all ooists is the prioe of our existence as a naval Power. Gibraltar, Malta, Siqaimanlt, Halifax, Ber- muda, Singapore, Houg Kong, not to mention others, have each their own port to play in any scheme of Imperial defence. They do not all require the same sort of protection. Ber- muda, for instanoe, surrounded by its shoal water, and guarded by its mine-fields, needs a garrison rather then big guns. Halifax, with its rampart of the Atlantic surges, is practioally immune from a torpedo flotilla. But they all have to be defended, if we are to retain the power of sending our fleets securely from one part of the globe to another, and it is essential that, one and all, they must be able to guard themselves and their priceless stores of coal and material without dependence on the Fleet.

div.head: ENGLAND AND GERMANY. MR. LEES BELLICOSE SPEECH. SENSATION IN GERMANY

div.p: Mr. Lees speech, mentioned in yesterdays telegram, has caused a sensation in Germany. The papers are angrily demanding an explanation. Some of them declare that Germany will now Work with redoubled energy in order to increase her sea power.

Mr. Lees now writes that he was incorrectly reported, and that what he said was that we must assume all naval powers to be possible enemies. Owing to the growth of. such naval powers, our possible enemies are more numerous than hitherto, and, consequently, we have to keep an anxious eye not only on the Medi- terranean but also on the North Sea. The "Standard" learns from Berlin that, unless Lord Lansdowne promptly repudiates the speech, Germany will ask for an explanation

div.head: NORTH SEA COMMISSION. A COMMISSIONER'S VIEWS

div.p: One of the foreign admirals on the commision of Enquiry, in an intervie with the correspondent said that, while the commisioners are at present convinced of the Russians good faith with reference to the presence of the torpedo boats, the commisioners are unable to believe there were any such boats. The admiral expected that the decision would be such as to enable the russians to walk out with their heads erect. (Reuter.)

Negotiations have been completed for the issue of a 5% Russian loan here. Nearly a millitard of france has been entrusted to the same firms which negotiated the previous Russian loans in france. It is understood the whole loan has been placed. The rate of issue is not stated. (Reuter.)

A man disguised as an officer, has assasinated Mr. Johnson, Procurator of the senate, and wounded his son. Mr. Johnson, was a Finn, but intensely unpopular as a pronounced pro-russian. His assailant has been arrested. (Reuter.)

div.head: Bank of Egypt
div.p: In regard to the recently declared 10% dividend of the Bank of Egypt, we may mention that this and a bonus of 15s. per share is equal to a net distribution to the shareholders of 16% of the bank's capital for one year.

div.head: The Mahmal Theft
div.p: It is suggested that, in future, to avoid theft of bullion and valu- able, such as occurred in the recent case of the mahmal, the Railway Administration should construct special cars fitted up as strong-rooms for the transport of treasure.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S TRIP.
div.p: Lord Cromer's speech here yesterday has made a very good impression, and his strongly- worded criticism on the growth of drinking habits has been taken to heart. Many of the omdehs who were among Lord Cromer's au- dience, were so impressed that they have told me that they intend to petition the Govern- ment against the manner in which liquor shops are being opened everywhere in the villages without let or hindance. I intend to found a local society hero to combat the alcohofic habit among the natives.
Lord and Lady Cromer and Lady Betrice Thynne paid a visit to one of the native kuttabs hero which is under the care of the Ministry of Public Instruction.
They also visited the native Sefa Coulop school. Della Bey, French consular agent here, and the members of the schoof committee recieved his lordship there.
The party took tea at the Moudir's residence and left at 3.15 pm for Wasta.
Lord and Lady Cromer are expected to arrive at Beni Hasan this evening. We hear that Lord Cromer is busily engaged on his annual report,

div.head: THE PLAGUE
div.p: During the week ending saturday only two cases of plague were reported throughout Egypt, one at suez and the other in the Toukh district.

div.head: BOVINE TYPHUS
div.p: During last week, 11 deaths from bovine typus were reported throughout Egypt, as against 6,164 deaths during the corresponding week last year. The total number of deaths to date amounts to 146,803

div.head: A CASE FOR ENQUIRY.
div.p: A cairo correspondent writes:- to the west of Abdeen-square is a nasty quarter where few sanitary and moral laws are enforced and where the grossest criminality prevails. While in that locality today I learned that in a quarrel between an armenian and three natives the armenian was so badly beaten that he, after a week or more, died, and nothing has been done to assailate or murderers. In fact, the principal was pointed out to me, and i was informed that a seargant of police was bribed to strike this mans name off the book for they all were arrested at the time of the quarrel. I wish this matter to be inquired into, for it is a most gross outrage if it is true as i am led to believe it is.

div.head: PROF FELIX'S RECITAL
div.p: Professor Felix's concert took place at the Khedivial Hotel on Saturday night as an- nounced, and considering the wet and tem- pestous weather, was well attended. We must congratulate the professor on his courage in fixing a more modest price for the tickets than is customary here for local artists, who ex- pect their kind friends to pay the same price for the pleasure of bearing them perform as they would do for distinguished artistes from Europe who can command audiences without the disagreeable touting system in vogue in this country. Mr. Felix's selection of piece was as it ought to have been, a happy one, as his silvery touch was shown off to perfection in most of them. If there was one piece more than another that elicited enthusiastic applause we might pick out an exquisite Nocturne of Chopin's (Opus 15 No. 2), in which an oft-recurring melody framed in flow mg cadenzas brought ont the pianist's remark able agility of finger. Wagner's "Choeur des Fileuses" from his "Vaissean Fantome" arranged by Lizt, was also much appreciated. Mr. Felix's wonderfully delicate touch is not so well suited to the heavier German music, which requires greater breadth of tone and a deeper sentiment. To our mind his conception of Mendelssohn's "Fruhlings Lied" was quite incorrect and far removed from the traditional one as taught in German Conaervatories,but on the other hand, the Duo by the same com- poser was faultlessly played.

Professor Felix was ably supported by Mrs. Frederick Cree, who sang, first, a romance by Giordano from Andrea Chenier with great refinement, and in the socond part Beetho- ven's famous "Per Pieta." Her passionate rendering of the presto, "Ah crudel I" quite carried away her audience, and on being encored she repeated it with even more verve than the first time. We must not omit the lovely little duet by Missa, "Les Roseaux Chanteurs," charmingly suug by Mrs. Cree and Mme. Felix, nor the instrumental trio performed very ably by Mr. H. and Mr. L. Suzan accom panied by Mr. Felix. Altogether a very plea- sant concert, but we must suggest that another time the pauses between the items should be curtailed, and that a performer does not ussually retire from the platform between two pieces bracketed a and b. All praise to Mr. Lifonti for the splendid Pleyel pianoforte lent for the oocasion.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUAKIN
H. M. S. Sealark Damaged.
div.p: H. M. S. ''Sealark'' arrived here from Sheikh Barghont on the 14th inst in a damaged ion- dition, having struck a rock about 4 miles off Sheikh Barghout whilst surveying. She had to come into Suakin for the necessery repairs, which have now been carried, out with the aid of divers and material obtained from the Sudan Government Railways
The "Sealark" after surveying here and at Sheikh Barghout, will probably go into dock and then continue her survey as far as Australia, which is her final destination.
The British S.S. "Dart" arrived from Eng- land on the 14th inst. with a very largo con- signment of rails and fishplates for the Suakin- Atbara Railways
The British S.S. "Thornley" arrived from England on the 16th inst, with a large consign- ment of iron sleepers for the railway.

div.head: THE POWELL COTTON EXPEDITION
div.p: According to intelligence just to hand, major Powell-Cotton, who left Khartoum on an expedition from the Nile to the Zambesi, was at Lado at the end of December. The expedition was making good progress and was meeting with every assistance from the officials. The explorer was in good health.

div.head: EGYPTIAN INVESTMENT AND AGENCY.
div.p: Some foolish complaints have appeared in some of the Cairo newspapers in regard to the allotment of the shares of the Egyptian Investment Agency, Limited. This outcry is absolute nonsense, for the company has no concession nor patents, and any one of the persons who consider themselves aggrieved in not having been allotted shares, can start as many companies for general financial business as they like on exactly similar conditions

div.head: KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE. LA TOSCA.
div.p: The Khedlvial Opera House reasserted itself in La Totea. The performance was in every way excellent. Signora Pandolfini obtain- ed and justified the welcome due to an old Cairo favorite both by her singing and by her acting. Signor Girand was pleasing and artistic, and Signor Polese was conspicuous for the excellence of his acting; we could wish: that all opera singers would give as much attention to details. "II Sagrestano" was amusing ; and we should like to hear more of Sig- nor Sala, the "timbre" of whose voice has some charm. Staging and choris were alike all that could be desired. We trust that other performances will maintain this level, and do away with the undoubtedly bad impression caused by Rigoletto (amongst Other pieces given). We would say one word as to the orchestra. Though, it is certainly composed of good musicians and directed by an efficient oonductor, there is often apparent a certain want of judgment, which might well be remedied, a lack of complete harmony with the singers, This, in light opera, where the melodies for the chief performers are the most prominent part, may not be so harmful in effect: but it is fatal in any such opera as Tristan, or indeed in any piece where the composer has devoted his attention to the music and not only to these who execute it In a word, we would wish to find (and we-have a right to expect) that sense of ensemble which it is the duty, as it should be the pleasure, of the Khedlvial Opera Honse to

div.head: ABBAS HELMY THEATRE. LUCIA DI LAMMERMOOR
div.p: Signora Isabella Sricher, the celebrated operatic artiste, who created such a furore at the Verdi Theatre in Cairo, and whose advent bad been anxiously awaited by a large section of the music-loving public, made her debut at the Abbas helmy Theatre on Satdrday Even- ing in Lucia di Lammermoor, and her magni- ficent performance reached to the full the highest expectations which had been formed regarding her. To say that Signora Svicher was admirable or excellent, would be but to very mildly express the quality of her per formapoe, from every point of view. Indeed, we venture to say that never has Egypt before been honored by the presence of two such magnificent artistes as Signs. Gemma Bellin- cioni and Sigus. Isabella Sricher, and from the rapturous applause so lavishly bestowed by enthusiastic and delighted audiences on each of these accomplished ladies, it is certain that the season will be a successful one. Signa. Svicher's Lucia, on Saturday, was an inter- pretation such as is seldom seen. Her singing was certainly a revelation to many present, and herr acting was of a high order and showed careful study of this mobt difficult rfllo. The tenor, Signor Tomiaaui being unwell, the role of Sir Edgard was sustained by Signor Pagani, who scored a distinct success. In fact, we think we have never heard Signor Pagani to better advantage. Signor Baldelli, in the small part of Raimondo, was excellent. The other minor parts were in good hands and the orchestra and chorus were fully up to their usual standard.

div.head: ANDREA CHENIER.
div.p: An admirable performance of Giordano's Andrea Chenier was given on Sunday night. Signor Pagani was in splendid voice and gave an excellent interpretation of the exceedingly trying title role. He was the success of the evening. Signora D. Bassich, who made her debut on this oocasion, gave a fairly good rendering of the part of Maddalens di.'Coigny, but her voice is not robust enough to stand her in good steed in an opera like Andrea Chenier. As Carlo Gerard, the baritone Badini, who possesses a voice of delightful freshness, was eminently successful. Sig. Montanari also scored a distinct success.

div.head: RIGOLETTO
div.p: Last night, a very excellent performance of Rigoletto was given at the Abhas Theatre. Excellent, we say, because in every respect the "ensemble" was a matter for admiration and, at times, even for Surprise. In Rigoletto Verdi began to realise in a way which he hitherto had not surmised, the important and extensive powers of his mind Up to this point he had written many tunes which had been hummed and sung throughout the whole world, but here he seemed to forego the enormous spirit of tune that was within him, and to give himself up entirely to the dramatic matter in hand. Last night's per formance of the opera was eminently successful. Signora Svicher, in the part of Gilda, was from every point of view a very great success ; her voice, which possesses some of the most exquisite qualities of modern vocalisation, was proved on this oocasion to possess an exquisite and, if one may use the adjective in connection with singing, a shining quality that impressed one enormously, by reason of the absolute purity of its evocation. Her range is enormous; she never misses her effects, and, to sum up, we regard her in no other light than that she is dazzlingly brilliant She was frantically applauded, especially after her delightful rendering of "Caro noms," which she was obliged to repeat Sig. Tomisani took the part of the Duke and enchanted everybody by the magnificence of his singing. He is a tenor of great power, and was in good form last night, enthusiasm on the part of the audience following everything he did. It stands to reason therefore that his rendering of "La Donna e mobile" waa triumphantly successful. In the part of Rigoletto Signor Badini sang excellently, though he did not impress us very much with his acting. The other parts were in good hands. The chorus was at times disappointing, but on the whole good, while the orchestra deserves credit. Tomorrow night, Signore Ballincioni will appear in Fedora

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The "Sehleswig" arrived at Alexandria at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon and most of the passengers, 92 first class and 52 second class, left by a special train for Cairo. Prince Lichtenstein, Count and countess von Arnim, Baron and Baroness de Serclaes, Count von Trautmansdorff, Count d'Ursel, and a number of other distinguished tourists arrived by this steamer. The complete list of passengers will be publsihed tomorrow. The "Schleswig" leaves Alexandria on wednesday afternoon at 5 o'clock as usual. A number of passengers have already been booked.
Conolel Sir Adolphus FitsGeorge, the third son of the late Duke of Cambridge, whose private secretary and equerry he was for many years, has arrived in Egypt from Marseilles
Sir John and lady Evans will leave for Khartoum next week
Miralai C.E. Wilson Bey has been appointed Commanant of Senasr military district

Liutenant-colonel Kenns, V.C., D.S.O. who was such a popular figure in Cairo society when the 21st Lancers were here, is to be married in London early next month to Angela Mary, youngest daughter of the late Hubers Hibbert and Mrs. Hubert Hibbert, of 2, beaufort-gardens.

The 2nd class of the order of the medjidieh has been conferred by the Khedive on Mr. Law, Judge of the mixed trubunals at Cairo, on the occasion of his retirement. His Highness will give audience to Judge Law on the 13th isnt.
Mr. A.H. Perry has gone to Port Said, and will return to Cairo on Wednesday
The great italian actor, Sig. Novelli, will arrive at alexandria from italy early next month

We regret to announce the death of well known Egyptian resident at Stamboul in the person of Mehmed Bey, member of the financial section of the Council of State, who died on the morning of the 24th ulto. at his residence at Beshiktash. The funeral took place in the afterooon at the expense of the Privy Purse. The late Bey was the son of Ibrahim Pasha, and grand-nephew of Mohamed Aly Pasha.

Among others to be seen dining in Shepheard's Restaurant, yesterday evening, we noticed Prince Lichtenstein, Baron von Drasch and a party, including Mr. and Mrs. Beckham, Mr. Baines and a party of 8, Marquis de Corea, Barou de Walzdorf and friends, Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Nixon and a party of 10, including Mrs. Mather, Mr. Morton, Mr. and Mrs. John dupec; Baron de Wecker, M. Ernpaiu and some Friends, Vicomte and Vicomtease de Fontarce, Vicomte de Sapucahy, Mr. and Mrs. O'Donnell Hiller, Liuut. and Mrs. von Meyer and a few friends, Mr, Mrs., and the Mieees Runerty, Mr. E. de Szeut-Ivauy and.friends Mr. P. de la Bella Casa and a party, etc.

The small dance at Shepheard's last night, it is needless to say, was a great success. Among the dancers we remarked. Mrs and miss carhardt, the misses bufferty, miss wildbur, miss H. Porter, the Misses budhead, Mrs. and the Misses haisen, the misses de gelshemen, the misses hillen, baron and baroness de vassilko, baron M. Oppenheim, baron Dobrenski, Chebalier de rappard, Herr von pohl, Mr. and Mrs Calame, Etc.
Mr. Givson Bowles, M.P., and Sir Curson and lady Wyllie are among the latest arrivals at the cataract hotel, assouan.

Other arrivals at the popular up river hotel include: mr and mrs e willis swan, mr and mrs r lenk, mrs h meyer, mr. j. lamont, mr c mohr, mr r l and miss gardiner messrs. div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
div.p: TRIBUNAL MIXTE DE COMMERCE
D'ALEXANDRIE
Los brasseurs de Munich contre La
Orown Brewery de l'Ibrahimieh.

Hier matin le Tribunal Mixte de Commerce d'Alexandrie, présidé par M. B. de, Zoltan, a renda son jugement dans l'instance en concurrence déloyale intenté par les principaux brasseurs de Munich & la Crown Brewery de l'I brahimish.
La Tribunal, adoptant les motifs exposés par F. W. Simond qui plaidait pour la Crowa Brewery, a débonté les brasseurs de Munich de leur demande comme mal fondée.

Les brasseurs de Munich avaient soutenu par l'organe de leur avocat, M. F. de Duinreicher, qu'ils étaient en droit d'interdire à la Crown Brewery, de se servir des dénominations: Bière de Munich et Bayrisch Beer.

Le Tribunal a retenu que quant à la pre. mière génomination, telle qu'elle était employée par la Crown Brewery, soit : Superior Munich Quality, alle oxolaait toute idée de provenance, mais désignait simplement une bière resseinblant à celle de Munich, brassée et fabriqnée comme celle brassée et fabriquée à Munich.

Que d'ailleurs la Crown Brewery avait offert par exploit d'huissier de remplacer la dénomii. nation de Superior Munich quality par toute autre au gré des demandeurs et notamment par celle de : Simili Munich, genre de Munich.

Qu'au surplus l'étiquette employée par la Crown Brewery ne laissait aucun doute et ne pouvait, telle qu'elle était libellée, induire le consommateur en erreur. Que les mots Crown Brewery s'y détachant à première vue, et l'inscription y contenue : Brassée et embouteillée à la brasserie de l'Ibrahimieh était amplemeut suffisante pour écarter toute idée de concur. rence déloyale.

Le Tribunal a également décidé quant au deuxième chef que la denomination Bayrich était entendu, tant en Egypte, que dans les principaux pays de l'Europe et en Bavière même, dans ua sens générique et non de provenance.
Le Tribunal & dono déboaté purement et simplement les Brasseurs de Munich de leur demande comine mal fondée et les a condamnés à tous les dépens.
LE SCANDALE ALEXANDRIN
Le compte-rendu détaillé de la plaidoirie de Me. Gaidotu, avocat de Mme Olga Constanti. nidis, paraltra demain.
